race.name: Leadville Trail 100 MTB
race.tagline: 100 miles at 10,000 feet. The Race Across the Sky.

vitals.aid_stations: 8+ aid stations with crew access points

climate.description: August at 10,000-12,600 feet means unpredictable weather—sun, rain, snow all possible

terrain.primary: Mixed mountain terrain—singletrack, fire roads, pavement
terrain.surface: Variable: buffed singletrack to rocky jeep roads to pavement

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Leadville buckle transcends cycling. Editorial +2 and overall +3 for legendary status.

history.origin_story: Created to bring economic life back to a struggling mining town. Ken Chlouber's vision: 'You're tougher than you think, and you can do more than you know.' The race defined mountain bike endurance.
notable_moments: The belt buckle became the ultimate participation trophy
history.reputation: The original 'Race Across the Sky.' The bucket-list race that started the endurance mountain bike movement.

course_description.character: Out-and-back with one massive climb (Columbine) and relentless terrain. The altitude is the course.

suffering_zones.label: Columbine Climb Begins
suffering_zones.desc: The defining climb. 3,000+ feet of gain to 12,600 feet.

suffering_zones.label: Columbine Summit
suffering_zones.desc: 12,600 feet. Thin air. Hike-a-bike likely. Turnaround point.

suffering_zones.label: Powerline Return
suffering_zones.desc: You've done this climb already. Now do it again on dead legs.

course_description.signature_challenge: Columbine. The climb to 12,600 feet breaks people. If you can't hike-a-bike at altitude, you can't Leadville.

prestige.explanation: This is THE mountain bike endurance race. Period. A Leadville buckle carries weight that transcends cycling. Finishing means something—the race has defined endurance riding for 30 years.

length.explanation: 100 miles of mountain terrain, with 12,000 feet of climbing at altitude. Most riders take 8-12 hours. This isn't a long ride—it's a day-long survival test.

technicality.explanation: Not technical by modern MTB standards—no drops, no rock gardens. But 100 miles of varied terrain requires solid bike handling. The Powerline descent punishes poor form.

elevation.explanation: 12,000 feet of climbing with significant portions above 11,000 feet. The vertical isn't the problem—the altitude at which you're climbing is. Your power drops 15-25%.

climate.explanation: August can bring anything: perfect bluebird or lightning and snow. The morning is cold (layers required), afternoon thunderstorms are common, and you're racing regardless.

altitude.explanation: You start at 10,200 feet. You summit at 12,600 feet. You're above 10,000 feet all day. If you don't acclimatize (7+ days recommended), you won't finish.

adventure.explanation: Leadville is a ghost town brought back to life by endurance racing. The history, the scenery, the community—it's more than a race. It's a pilgrimage.

biased_opinion.summary: Leadville isn't the hardest 100-mile race technically. It's not even the most scenic. But it's the most meaningful. The history, the community, the belt buckle—finishing Leadville changes how you see yourself as an endurance athlete. It's a rite of passage.
strengths: The prestige: A Leadville buckle is universally recognized. It means something.
The community: Crews, spectators, aid stations—everyone is invested in your success.
The history: 30 years of legends. Racing the same course as Tinker and the greats.
weaknesses: The lottery: You can't just sign up. You enter and hope. Qualifying helps odds.
Altitude: Non-negotiable. If you can't acclimatize, don't start.
Not gravel-specific: This is mountain biking. Different skills, different bike, different training.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want to test yourself against the defining endurance mountain bike race, this is it. The altitude is the great equalizer—respect it or suffer.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: The belt buckle pictures look great on Instagram. Getting one requires a level of altitude preparation most people underestimate. DNF rates are real—and most DNFs are altitude-related, not fitness-related.
consequences: You need 7-14 days at altitude before race day. That's significant vacation time.
The race is expensive: $350 entry, travel, lodging in a tourist town, crew needs.
A 12-hour finish is respectable. Sub-9 is elite. Manage expectations accordingly.
black_pill.expectation_reset: This isn't a gravel race you 'add on' to your season. Leadville requires dedicated preparation: altitude training, altitude acclimatization, and altitude race-day strategy. Respect the sky, or it will humble you.

final_verdict.one_liner: The mountain bike endurance race that defines the category. Bucket list for a reason.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes—if you're serious about endurance riding and willing to commit to proper altitude preparation. No—if you can't take time to acclimatize or haven't trained specifically for high-altitude suffering.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want Leadville's prestige without the lottery: Leadville Camp (August warmup). If you want 100 miles without altitude: Unbound 200 (longer, lower, different). If you want Colorado gravel: SBT GRVL is lower altitude, pure gravel.

logistics.airport: Denver (DEN) - 2.5 hours to Leadville. Consider arriving days early.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Book immediately after lottery acceptance. Leadville sells out. Consider Frisco/Buena Vista as backup.
logistics.food: Tennessee Pass Cafe is tradition. Pack nutrition—options are limited.
logistics.packet_pickup: Thursday-Friday at the Leadville 6th Street Gym.
logistics.parking: Start line parking requires very early arrival. Shuttle from downtown available.
